quoteFirst: Thaneford had risen, his teeth clenched upon his lower lip, a half cry choking in his throat. Together our eyes fastened on the dial of his watch, where the hands now pointed to
quoteLast: o'clock. With one convulsive movement he snatched up the time-piece, and dashed it in golden ruin to the floor; then he sprang toward me, and I knew in another moment those strong hands, with their black-tufted knuckles, would be gripping at my throat.
title: In Jeopardy
author: Sutphen, Van Tassel, 1861-1945

quoteFirst: Back into his tumbled blankets he got. As the strangled flame of his lamp slowly died he reached to his trousers, dug out his watch, and glanced at it. It was now
title: Cat o' mountain
author: Friel, Arthur O. (Arthur Olney), 1885-1959; Humphreys, Donald S. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: How still the quiet night must have been was impressed upon him by the fact that he distinctly heard, and counted, the strokes of a church clock which must have been at least six miles away.  He remembers looking at his watch and noting that there was a slight difference between his own and the church time.  He made it
quoteLast: .  With the dying away of the last vibrations of the distant bell the silence and the solitude of the place seemed to return and settle down upon it with increased insistence.  While he was working it had not troubled him, but beside the black shadows thrown by those hoary stones it had the effect almost of a presence.
title: Malvina of Brittany
author: Jerome, Jerome K. (Jerome Klapka), 1859-1927

quoteFirst: When day came, about half past three in the morning, more than three hours had passed since the head of the comet had collided with the earth; the nucleus had passed in a southwesterly direction, and the earth was still entirely buried in the tail. The shock had taken place at eighteen minutes after midnight; that is to say, fifty-
quoteLast: , Paris time, exactly as predicted by the president of the Astronomical society of France, whose statement our readers may remember.
title: Omega: The Last days of the World
author: Flammarion, Camille, 1842-1925

quoteFirst: This event comes off about midday; of course, not always exactly at that hour, but as Zu-Vendis is situated not far from the Line, although—being so high above the sea it is very temperate—midday and the falling of the sunlight on the altar were generally simultaneous. Today the sacrifice was to take place at about
title: Allan Quatermain
author: Haggard, H. Rider (Henry Rider), 1856-1925

quoteFirst: He was in constant hope of receiving a battle cruiser. But Admiral Troubridge decided to act on his own responsibility.
quoteLast: of August 6 (i.e. 0.08, August 7) he gave orders to his four cruisers and his eight destroyers to steam Southward at full speed for the purpose of intercepting the _Goeben_. He also signalled to the _Dublin_ (Captain John Kelly) at that moment coming from Malta to join him with the two extra destroyers, to head her off. He reported his decision to the Commander-in-Chief.
title: The World Crisis, Volume 1 (of 6)
author: Churchill, Winston, 1874-1965
